verb.description: To overburden, overload. Now: specifically to expose (a vessel) to too great a force of wind by using too much sail.
To press or insist on (a point, etc.) unduly.
To put too much pressure on (a person); to overwork or overburden.

origin: Mid 19th century; earliest use found in Edward Forbes (1815–1854), natural historian. From overpress<br>late Middle English (in an earlier sense). From over- + press.
